bibl.title: Letter from Simon Flexner to Emilie Lawrence Reed, May 28, 1928

div1.p: Flexner thanks Emilie Lawrence Reed for a memento of Walter Reed.

div1.head: Letter from Simon Flexner to Emilie Lawrence Reed, May 28, 1928

opener.dateline:
THE ROCKEFELLER INSTITUTE
FOR MEDICAL RESEARCH
66TH STREET AND AVENUE A
NEW YORK
May 28, 1928

div1.p:
A little while ago the paper cutter
with my initials, which you so kindly sent me, was re-
ceived. I wish to thank you very much for it. You
say that it was made at the Walter Reed Hospital, and
I am wondering whether it was made by a disabled sold-
ier and if so, if it is permissible for anyone to send
a contribution for the benefit of disabled men.

You of course saw the announcement
of the death in Africa of Dr. Noguchi from yellow fever.
The disease which your wonderful husband did so much to
check still claims its victims in remote places. Dr.
Noguchi is the third of the men who were at one time
at the Rockefeller Institute to die of the fever, while
engaged in its scientific study.

I hope that you are quite well. Your
grandchildren must be grown up now. May I ask you kind-
ly to remember me to your son and daughter?
div1.closer:
Yours sincerely, (Simon Flexner) Mrs. Walter Reed,
c/o Surgeon Gen. Merritt W. Ireland,
War Department,
Washington, D.C.
